pubStmt.avail:
THIS TEXT IS AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT THE WORLD only as part of the British National Corpus at nominal charge FOR ACADEMIC RESEARCH PURPOSES SUBJECT TO A SIGNED END USER LICENCE HAVING BEEN RECEIVED BY OXFORD UNIVERSITY COMPUTING SERVICES, from whom forms and supporting materials are available.
THIS TEXT IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR COMMERCIAL RESEARCH AND EXPLOITATION unless terms have first been agreed with the BNC Consortium Exploitation Committee. Apply in the first instance to Oxford University Computing Services.
It is your responsibility, as a user, to ensure that an End User Licence is in place. For your information, the Terms of the End User Licence are set out in the corpus header, which is likely to have a file name similar to "corphdr" or "CORPHDR".
Distribution of any part of the corpus under the terms of the Licence must include a copy of the corpus header. Distribution of this corpus text under the terms of the Licence must include this header embodying this notice.
THE EXACT CONDITIONS OF USE FOR THIS TEXT ARE NOT CURRENTLY KNOWN TO THE ARCHIVING AGENCY. PLEASE CONTACT THE DATA CAPTURE AGENCY NAMED IN THIS HEADER FOR FURTHER INFORMATION.

encDesc.projDesc: See the project description in the corpus header for information about the British National Corpus project.
encDesc.refsDecl: Canonical references in the British National Corpus are to text segment (<s>) elements, and are constructed by taking the value of the n attribute of the <cdif> element containing the target text, and concatenating a dot separator, followed by the value of the n attribute of the target <s> element.

respStmt.name: dominic

s.w: I suddenly thought that on the advert that's gone in
On the advert that's gone in I did wonder whether to put please respond by such and such a date?
If they don't respond by the date, you know do it quickly
That's all we did for the statutory undertakers.
Just drew them a whacking great circle round it and

pause.w: Erm

s.w: So I'll speak to Dennis for er addresses.
Is there a phone number in the ad or just an address?

ptr.w: A phone number as well yeah.

pause.w: But we'll just have a word withAnna-Lee and if, I think you know, she'll say what's it concerning and if I'm not there well she can put them through to you.

s.w: Erm so you say, are we saying that we're gonna leave the police till we've got some dates?

pause.w: And the

s.w: Well we know when we're gonna do it don't we?
Well we know it's the last week in April or something
Well we wan na know whether we were gonna try and do them all in that week?
I think the plan that goes to to the police thank you needs to show the i interview sites on it.

pause.w: You remember we had, on the Ormskirk one we did one that had a study area on it?

s.w: But we also had one that showed the individual locations.
And I think that was the one that went to the police.
Er and the fire brigade and, and so on.
Yeah cos they'll want to know.
And all you're doing is warning them that they will, the things will be there and we'll make sure that if a emergency vehicle comes along erm
But they will know your precise dates won't they?
Well they'll want to know precise dates.
I can't remember that we did actually.
No I don't know whether we do give them, even the precise dates.
It isn't really much use then is it, just giving them a rough ?

pause.w: Well we'll have a look back in, I'll have a look back in the file and see what we did last time.

s.w: Erm Do you wanna do that, have a look at what we'd said in Ormskirk
I think I wrote to them if I remember rightly.
Erm now we need to do something about layout plans.

pause.w: So we need to get some if we're going to work on ordnance survey ones we'll need to sort something on that.

s.w: Have to have a chat with Anyway you're not in an immediate rush to do that are you?
What have you told only you haven't told Gwyllam anything have you?
Cos you, what you've told him is did you talk about chapter eight?

I, I just said to him, when he said we've got these census point ahead I said well we've got certain restrictions, you know, we've certain rules and regulations we've gotta comply with I mean I didn't reel off any of this blah.

pause.w: But I said oh, are you familiar with setting up roadside interviews and for this type of thing?

s.w: Oh yes, we've got such and such a fella out there that does nothing but that out all day long.

shift.w: And yet they didn't have any signs so I think he's talking through his hat.

s.w: But what he probably means is that they set up signs for
So I mean I would have thought they've gotta comply with the same
I think the thing is, actually, just thinking about it, there will be a Welsh version of this if there is one if you see what I mean?
If there isn't one then we, we er er it er oh mind you I suppose there's no hassle to them to put a Welsh thingy, anyway I'll look at that.
Right, now the other thing is that what Jim's doing which is that programme, how is that coming along?
What I did was I got I went down to the print room and I got a piece of A one paper and I mean if you want to use Chris
Chris over in Chester office, see if, that one would, oh mind you there isn't a chair there is there?
Yes, two day a day and a half or something, two days?
So, you know, there's desks around anyway
and erm er that's what I used if you want to borrow that you can.
And do it in pencil and just, and then we can rub it out
and change things and so on, yeah.

vocal.w: Well it's easy to change isn't it?

s.w: Because presumably Peter will need to incorporate that in an overall programme.

pause.w: When we look at the highway side.

s.w: So it's just the traffic side which I'm dealing with here?

pause.w: Cos that's all I'm dealing with.
Okay and perhaps erm perhaps you'd also like to l would you like to look at this side of things as well?

s.w: No, the, the layout plans, do, do some layout plans.
Marty's done them before you see haven't you?
So I'm, I'm just trying to look at the ones for and then we'll go from there.

pause.w: Okay, is that alright?

s.w: Now, have I given either of you task schedules for this
So I need to do that don't I?
Er in fact I never gave telephone call it's no good telling me to do something
Task schedules, ooh I'll have to get the form.
Okay, so you want a task schedule for doing doing the traffic report?
And also for doing the programme.

pause.w: Yeah?

s.w: And you want a task schedule for organizing this, it's a bit unspecific isn't it?

pause.w: Erm how is that then?

s.w: Er you happy to leave things as they are for the minute?
Yeah, the only other thing like when you were saying about site layouts, if there's any maps that we need, and that's including maps for coding, wall maps, you know, large scale.
Well obviously we've got to progress into that.
We need to prepare some zone plans and gazetteers maybe.
Erm oh well I'll er the other thing I was thinking of is that er we could be looking er towards beginning, you know even now, to doing a trips network and things like that.
There's no real reason why you, say, shouldn't start to build up the data on that.
Erm y y you know you, you could do a diagram and presumably the person to speak to would be Billy or maybe Peter cos I think Peter did the bulk of the work.
Beverley did a lot of the actual sort of dogsbody work, you know, the actual doing of it.
Erm so you need to build up a picture of what you've got erm but there's no real reason why we shouldn't be working on that now it seems to me.

Yes beginning, you know, we, we know what we're trying to do obviously we don't necessarily know every, every node in the network erm Cos obviously once you start doing that, or when we start doing tr the, the journey run things erm we're going to need to know what we're wanting.

pause.w: So there'll be two sides of it c er

s.w: Well there, there won't be any will there?
But anyway I mean it's all part of the picture.
What I'm getting at is there's no reason why we need, we should wait until after the surveys to start looking at trips.
Which is what happened on Ormskirk.
Mind you it was partly because we didn't get a programme.
But there's no reason, and on as well.

pause.w: Alright?

s.w: Right, so me and Jim had a chat the other day just looking at the the roadside entries and the counts and I was sort of saying if we work on the basis that we want between ten and twelve people, twelve people maximum
erm I think we're be able to do all the counts with that number of people including the St David's roundabout and
but we do need to clarify exactly what you want on that.
Whether you want samples doing cos that's gonna take more people, or whether you're just doing ins and outs and stuff like that.
And on the other roundabout for that matter.
Yeah I've got a seminar in Manchester .

ptr.w: we're just talking now this, this is, this is one we're discussing.

s.w: Oh well just south of Caernarvon on the first section erm between Caernarvon and ?
Gwyneth haven't really started on doing any of that work yet.
And they need to do traffic.

pause.w: And also they need to confirm the traffic erm turning 099 junction at er I can never pronounce it, beginning with an L.

s.w: And er maybe count, maybe do their traffic counts out of that as well.
So the guy that was in charge of those schemes with Gwyneth
was at the meeting or came into the meeting to explain about the schemes.
Cos that was one of the things we talked about

ptr.w: Vernon somebody or other I think his name was.

s.w: Yes, need to do that this week.
But they, this, these, well he's got a copy now of the report and he's gon na c comment back on what
Do Welsh Office want any more
erm and they should comment this week about what extra bits they think they could perhaps cover.
So maybe a few more turning counts the census
And that wasn't where I well I haven't been
particularly looking for work from that particular

unclear.w: to know is they raised er the question about the er counts we're doing for the Caernarvon link

s.w: which is part of this study.
They want us to divorce the staff time
and charge it against the Caernarvon job.
Yeah which is to our benefit cos we get
What about the work for Gwyneth?
What do we charge that to?
They don't want us to charge it to extra to works?
We could have a two point six seven multiplier
Er er er as far as they're concerned any extra work is just an enhancement of the rate to the bypass erm rate, point six two percent.

unclear.w: said we need approval for extra work

s.w: he said well it's just, it's time costs, it's just an extension of the
Are they wanting a budget figure from us?
We're gon na have to put
What was Paul saying about the wedding then?

pause.w: I said, I said have you invited Aunty Joan and them?

s.w: He said oh I've invited Aunty Joan but nobody else cos I didn't fancy any of the others.
And has he invited Joan to the day do and that?
But he hasn't invited any to the night .

pause.w: I think I might have his conscience by saying that I don't mind.

s.w: Well for what they see I can understand him asking Joan and Graham erm maybe they've gotta watch how much they're
I know but an extra four people's not gonna cost that much more is it?
Why I asked him is because he had a wedding invitation for Rob and Jen
Well to be honest I can understand why he's not asking them.
You know they'll make up with friends you know, what family they're not asking won't they?
No it's not as if you're all close is it?
And I mean we haven't seen them since ours hardly have we?

shift.w: Oh I had a really good day today.

s.w: I didn't go till about half ten ah no cos I had a few letters and stuff to write first and I thought right I'll just take me time and, cos I wanted to I didn't wanna go faster than you know than I should, I should have done sort of thing cos I wanted to time it properly.

pause.w: Erm it took me an hour and a quarter.

s.w: And it's exactly sixty miles into the middle of Caernarvon.

ptr.w: And that's where the survey's gonna be, right in the middle is it?

s.w: Well no but that's where I had to go.
See you can allow a few extra miles for getting
So you wanna allow yourself a an hour and half really don't you?

pause.w: Do you think, or not?

s.w: Well I don't think so because that, I mean there won't be any traffic hardly
when I'm going so I'll just allow the same.
And then I should do it in an hour.
You know I'll be leaving at about half five.

pause.w: No, not b about quarter past five I'll be leaving, five to quarter past.

s.w: That's allowing a a good hour and a quarter.
But it's not gonna take me longer at that time of the morning than it has done today at eleven o'clock or so is it?
Coming home it took me a bit longer cos it was all that delay at the hill.
Oh aye that's right I heard it on the radio.
Oh no the rest of it, it's not too bad, it's not a bad journey, it's quite pleasant really.
So I went straight to the county offices and saw the rooms you know where we're going to

ptr.w: Can you put the stuff on the walls?

s.w: Erm I'm not gonna put them on the walls.
They've got you know like these big boards, free standing boards
Gonna have some of them there's three I think and they're really long ones.
Er so I'm gonna have them but she showed me the small room, what they call the small room, well that was huge well it will be perfect for what we want.
Really plush, you know all the carpets
Erm and then she said oh and this is the other one and it was like all er it was bigger again obviously, and all the tables in a square

ptr.w: Yeah but each seat ooh excuse me each seat had a microphone built into the desk.

s.w: But I thought that'd be more of a hindrance than a help
for what we were doing so when I got back to the office I rung and I tempor well provisionally booked this, the smallest of the two which I think will be brill.

ptr.w: So what did she say about the money when you tried her for less money?

s.w: Well that one you have to ring the head office in Bangor, I had to ring her when I got back.
They only er showed me the rooms, they do the bookings and I just said
And it's actually in the like the council offices?

pause.w: They have all like them chambers there as well you know?
But I just said that it was for the Welsh Office cos I thought if er they knew it was for a Authority you know?

unclear.w: I said do you, do you think there'd be any discount er with it being a block booking?

s.w: And she didn't say no full stop, she said oh she said I'm not sure she said, I'd have to enquire about that.
So I just thought she's gon na yeah if it was out of the question she could have said oh no that's it, there's a flat rate so I

ptr.w: thing is with them Welshies they probably haven't tried to bloody they haven't got the sense.

s.w: If somebody else was trying to book it, one of those Welshy types, they haven't got the sense to ask

ptr.w: No, I said well I said that I'd appreciate it cos it's worth a go and she said oh yes I agree with you there.

s.w: So then I thought oh I'll go and find er the offices again, Church Street.

And we'd gone a roundabout way the last time we were there and I thought oh I'll give it a go, anyway I walked straight down this road, have a look oh yes, turn up here anyway I, I sort of got me bearings and I thought oh yes it's just down here he's in the field just down there.

ptr.w: Do you wanna go or not or go straight to your nan's?

s.w: Go straight to nan's, call on the way back.

pause.w: Couldn't see him.

s.w: Erm so I went straight to this place and there was a fella downstairs, his secretary was erm out on her lunch.
Anyway I said oh I said you're not expecting me, said who I was and where I was from.
I said I called in to see either Michael or the secretary, Mirelda her name is.
And er so he said alright.
I said I'm also gonna be che cheeky and see if I can use your toi he said oh yes he said, go and help yourself he said there's a kettle down there, make yourself a drink, make yourself at home.
So anyway I thought I won't have a drink cos if this secretary wasn't there I didn't know how long she'd be so er but I di I went upstairs to where we had the meeting with Mike the other week.
And erm Joe his partner was there so I had a really good chat to him.
What do you mean his partner like?
Is it just like a little firm?

pause.w: And this Michael's one of the partners in the firm?

s.w: No there's just them in the office.

pause.w: Erm so I had a chat to him.

s.w: He drew me a little plan of how to get to W H Smiths and that.
What the hell do you wanna go to Smiths for?

pause.w: So I had a walk up the town and called in Tesco's and got a bit of shopping.

s.w: Is it much of a place, Caernarvon?
They have a market there don't there?

pause.w: So I went to Smiths, got this map

s.w: But I don't think I'll need it.
It's just a one to twenty five thousand, a Pathfinder.
Cos I picked up the Chester to Wrexham one instead of the Snowdonia one.

pause.w: Caernarvon's on the Snowdonia map.

s.w: An O S one to fifty thousand and that's what I thought I'd picked up this morning to take with me but when I looked it was Chester and Wrexham so it didn't do me much good.
So I thought oh well I'll buy this other one and
Claim it back off the firm?

shift.w: Three pound ninety something chicken butties and bag of crisps and that, it was nice.

s.w: Cos I'd parked on the top of this multi-storey car park at the offices, is it called?
Erm I parked on the top.
So it wasn't all dark and that
cos I wanted to be looking at me plans.
And I ate me butty there on top.
In the pouring bloody rain and howling wind I expect.
It was, yeah it was horrible .

pause.w: So then I just had a drive round all the sites.

s.w: Did you find them all alright?
I know where I'm going now with er all of them.

pause.w: You know and getting to them, I know how to get from one to the other without going, you know?

s.w: I've got a good idea of where everywhere is.

pause.w: So I was quite pleased.

shift.w: When I got back ooh you know I told you about that job?

s.w: We've put a bid in for Arrow Park.
Winning some bloody jobs aren't you.
What have they done, dropped their prices?
Well Rob's doing them isn't he?
Oh they have had to drop their prices.

They've had to go for the we did them a few sort of quotes on the survey side of this Arrow Park and er we've gotta, you know, really stick to this tight budget because it's the only way you can get them no matter what people are telling you erm about the recession being over, people still want things for nothing.

pause.w: So this survey might have to be done at the beginning of April.

s.w: But it's not a big one so
Well when's these in Caernarvon, the end of April?
Starting the twenty seventh of April.

pause.w: So I shall be enjoying myself at the wedding
Er yeah so we'll have this thing at Arrow Park to do.

s.w: We'll looking into doing we need to know how many cars gone in, how many cars go out
But there's residential sections as well.
And then see how long each vehicle stayed there.
You'll have to er take the registration of every bloody car!

pause.w: It's probably because they're taking over the er accident and emergency department from Clatterbrick it's shutting down and it's all going to Arrow Park.

s.w: Well that's not why we're doing it.
That's what's happening, it was on the radio the other day.
This is just well I mean it maybe connected with that but we're doing it because they want to increase the car parks .

pause.w: So we're looking to do it with tape recorders on the busiest entrance and you know and just say car D five one four R G M blah blah blah.

shift.w: Get them all down and then the person on the quieter entrance can just write them down.

s.w: But you don't necessarily have to say the whole number.
You know you can just say D five one four.
Well that's what you wanna, so much quicker wouldn't it, just say the Escort D five one four.
Yeah, you don't even have to say the the make.

pause.w: And then erm they all get punched into the, Rob's got a special computer programme thing, you punch them all in er and then it does a ma a matching thing.
And it come, at the end of the day it comes out with all the ones it's matched, the duration it's been there and er makes it a damned sight easier basically.

s.w: Then we've got in June we're supposed to be doing journey time surveys and traffic counts on the M sixty three.
I won't get off at this one, no?
Erm now they're talking of doing roadside interviews in both directions on the motorway on the slip roads.
Be a big job that will.

pause.w: So I hope it comes off.

s.w: Loads of money , you'll be minted.

pause.w: It's about time we got something, don't, you know for months we scratched round looking like we're busy, now we're meeting ourselves backwards, coming backwards.

ptr.w: But I mean I'm already starting stopping later, unintentionally you know, just cos I wanna finish something.

s.w: Here I turn now do I?

pause.w: Well that this is the bloody supermarket.
Er yeah I've already got over thirty hours credit.

s.w: And you're not supposed to have more than thirty even though Mike's got about a hundred and three.
How the hell he's wangled it, honest to god!

ptr.w: Well he must be fiddling it cos he, he's never bloody worked it.

pause.w: So erm and I, I can't just take a flexi-day because I'm already, I've already got leave to use.

s.w: So I'm gon na see how I get on an if I keep doing it I'm just gonna get it as overtime.

pause.w: What are you having?
Are you coming in?

s.w: No, I don't wanna see Jean.

pause.w: Oh she's there.

ptr.w: I know, I couldn't long time getting

s.w: Well I was allowing you time with your leg but we thought you've got the telly on loud.
Oh aye I have really, yes

pause.w: We've been in chinky we've brought our tea.

s.w: We've been to the chippy, we haven't had any tea yet.
So can we eat them here please ?
Right you take them in there the table.
Yeah we can do, saves stinking out in here.
You'd better put something on it.

pause.w: Oh there's nothing to

ptr.w: I'll not ask you in there with the table because there wasn't enough room.

s.w: There's a little table there, a little folding table there.

shift.w: Go on go and sit on

s.w: No you wanna rest your leg.
Ooh don't matter about resting me r about resting me leg.
We've just been to see Jean there at the chippy.
Looks like a teddy bears' picnic
No we'll have them out of the paper, we'll save on washing up, thank you.
I'm alright, I d I want a butty thank you.
Michael how, how many rounds do you want?

vocal.w: So they'd better be nice seeing as we've been all the way

ptr.w: Just get me the marge out of there

s.w: Ooh it comes and goes Martine, it's nearly driving me daft to be honest.

pause.w: Is it gone a bit easier?
Has it gone a bit easier for you?
What do you want?

s.w: Er just do you want one or two?
I don't want one thank you.
You know where the salt and vinegar is don't you?
There's plenty on them, they're alright.
Oh there in er in the cupboard there.
Do you want a few chips on a plate nan?
I've only just got just had a big dinner love.
I had a la lamb chop cabbage
roast potatoes rhubarb, stewed rhubarb, Ron's stewed rhubarb.
Oh it was very nice and it's his first rhubarb.

ptr.w: give your mum a cou just a couple of sticks.

s.w: Yeah she was only saying ours has started to come through

pause.w: Oh they are nice
Ooh.

s.w: Don't bother with a plate for that.

pause.w: What did you say?

s.w: I, he could have had that straight on the paper.
I said there was no need to have got him a plate.
Spoiling him, he doesn't have a plate at home for his bread and butter.
Well y your dad likes a lot of a out of the paper, I du nno.
It ta tastes nicer out of a paper.
If I, if I'm out yes, I li I like them in a pa in a, in a paper, you know, but er I've got no cake to offer you, I can't some biscuits.
No, I'll be alright after this.

ptr.w: We haven't had chips for ages have we?

s.w: Oh well if you haven't had chi or haven't done for a long time you enjoy them.
Nan you'll love why don't you go back and watch your programme and have a sit down and we won't be two ticks eating these.

ptr.w: Your mum had a what did she have?

pause.w: Oh she'd been up to Pearks

s.w: She bought a steak and kidney pie now then, no she didn't have chips steak and kidney pie and some er couple of iced buns, she bought me a, an ordinary pie.
So I had that at dinner time.
Oh me mum's been here today?

ptr.w: And she called she did ask the girl for er two er cream doughnuts

s.w: and she, she's a new girl, your mum said
and she gave her iced buns.
There was all sort of icing on and cream as well.
But I must admit they were very nice.
Me mum's been here today has she?
Yeah, she come about half past twelve?
Oh she said yesterday she might call.
And she went from here about er well she said she was going at quarter past two.
I said it is quarter past two if you I'm not pushing you off but you've got to be somewhere on time.

unclear.w: have a we had a bit of a chat

s.w: and er she went sort of thing.
So I always take my dinner in there.
Well aye, might as well have a bit of comfort.
And and then I come back in here, I always get my sweet and take that back again.

pause.w: I watch Blockbusters

s.w: Oh yes, we had ab er well while you were in the shower.
and then I always stop and watch the news.

pause.w: So I come er come in here after and er washed up

s.w: and I'd just peeled an orange to be honest
I just fancied an orange, I thought oh
And I'd just that very minute sat down.
Why don't you go and sit down again and we'll come in as soon as we've finished these.
So you can rest your leg.
Are you sure you don't want any biscuits only I haven't any ?

ptr.w: Not I am without cake but Irene brought me some small ones yesterday

s.w: and I've only just finished our, our Christmas er bun loaf sort of thing, you know
Right, I'll go and finish my orange.
Okay, we won't be a minute.
Ooh you're gonna have a cup of tea aren't you?

pause.w: Are you having one anyway nan?

s.w: Yes, there's the water in the kettle and everything in.
Well o I'll, if you put it to boil

pause.w: They're nicer than our chips.

ptr.w: Do you want tea bags or loose tea?

s.w: Do you want tea Martine or lemonade or ?

ptr.w: Erm I'll have tea please, yeah.

pause.w: We usually have a cuppa after don't we?

s.w: I'm just saying these chips are nicer than the Bottley chips.
Oh aye, we'll be coming here again.

vocal.w: Your dad always likes them from here.

s.w: Oh they're your mum and dad now aren't they?

pause.w: Got nowhere local for chips.
Oh lovely, thank you.
Smashing.
You get a good One thirty, that's not bad is it that?

s.w: Now then I'm going to leave you to it.
Okay, we'll be through in a minute.

ptr.w: I'll just go and finish my orange.

s.w: We'll be through in a bit.

pause.w: I think we pay more than that ?

s.w: I think fish is over a pound, yeah.

ptr.w: Fish is normally about one twenty odd, oh aye.

s.w: So with the chips as well this is about one sixty.

pause.w: Or does three sixty sound more like it?

s.w: Erm three sixty that would be one eighty.
Yeah maybe it was three sixty.
She must be having one, put them straight in the cups.

pause.w: She must have made one.
How ?
Ooh come on.

s.w: Do you want any more chips?
It was a good idea of mine I thought.

vocal.w: Have to take the door off the hinges to get your head out if it gets any bigger.
